messages.message: Hi, i’m confused by our API docs. If you’re community (and therefore don’t have a organisation ID) what is the value of <ORGANIZATION-ID> in the APIs listed here: https://aihub.instabase.com/docs/aihub/apis/api-reference/filesystem-v2/index.html
Do you mean if you are a community (and therefore don’t have a organisation ID)?
Sorry yes, will update the message

Yea, I can see why this is confusing.

For community context, the urls should be `<user-id>/my-repo/fs/Instabase Drive` .
For commercial context, the urls should be `<organization-id>/<user-id>/fs/<drive name>` .
Thanks, I have since found another place in the docs this is listed, but it isn’t carried through to these pages. I’ll open a ticket
Looking in this screenshot for the commercial S3 bucket row, it has `<user-id>` as a value. What should this be set to if you’re in a shared space? Is it still your user ?

It’s the name of the workspace. If you want to access your personal workspace it’s your user Id. If you want to access a shared workspace, it’s the name of the shared workspace as listed on My Hub. @jean @Adam it would be great if we could update documentation accordingly
Thanks for the ping, @hannah. I really appreciate it on docs-related threads.

PR to address this: https://github.com/instabase/aihub-docs/pull/72/files

@Lee, I’ve pinged you for review. I’m out of office from tomorrow till the new year, but @Rosie will keep an eye on this PR and help address issues and get it merged.

For reference, here’s the adjusted version of the screenshot above. I’ve replaced user-id with workspace on the commercial lines, and changed “user” to “account” because it isn’t the kind of user but the kind of account they are accessing (aka context) that matters here.

The PR also includes changes to the converse API page, the filesystem page, and the authorization page.
